name: Apple
linkInfo: Tesler worked at PARC before moving to Apple.

name: Apple
linkInfo: Steve Jobs and other Apple folks visited PARC and borrowed many ideas for Lisa and Macintosh. Apple paid PARC for the visit.

name: BCL
linkInfo: Pask was a visiting professor at the BCL, 1960-61.

name: BCL
linkInfo: Maturana visited the BCL, 1967-68.

name: BCL
linkInfo: Ashby was a professor at the BCL, 1961-72.

name: DARPA
linkInfo: Lickider worked at DARPA, 1962-64.

name: DARPA
linkInfo: DARPA supported Engelbart’s research.

name: DARPA
linkInfo: DARPA funded research that led to the Internet.

name: DARPA
linkInfo: Taylor worked at DARPA, 1965-69.

name: Design Methods Conf.
linkInfo: Owen, Pask, Rittel, Archer, and Alexander attended the first DM Conference.

name: Design Methods Conf.
linkInfo: Owen, Pask, Rittel, Archer, and Alexander attended the first DM Conference.

name: Design Methods Conf.
linkInfo: Owen, Pask, Rittel, Archer, and Alexander attended the first DM Conference.

name: Design Methods Conf.
linkInfo: The Design Methods Movement is a precursor to “design thinking.”

name: Design Methods Conf.
linkInfo: Owen, Pask, Rittel, Archer, and Alexander attended the first DM Conference.

name: Design Methods Conf.
linkInfo: Owen, Pask, Rittel, Archer, and Alexander attended the first DM Conference.

name: Design Thinking
linkInfo: IIT/ID helped launch and promote “design thinking.”

name: IIT Institute of Design
linkInfo: IIT/ID helped launch and promote “design thinking.”

name: Internet
linkInfo: Engelbart’s lab was one of the first two connections on what became the Internet.

name: Soft Systems
linkInfo: “Soft systems” is a precursor to “design thinking.”

name: University of Utah
linkInfo: Sutherland turned Utah into the premiere school for computer graphics in the mid 1960s.

name: University of Utah
linkInfo: Sutherland had a number of graduate students who went on to impressive careers.

name: University of Utah
linkInfo: Sutherland had a number of graduate students who went on to impressive careers.

name: University of Utah
linkInfo: Sutherland had a number of graduate students who went on to impressive careers.

name: University of Utah
linkInfo: Sutherland had a number of graduate students who went on to impressive careers.

name: University of Utah
linkInfo: Sutherland had a number of graduate students who went on to impressive careers.

name: WiRed
linkInfo: Negroponte was a co-founder of WiReD.

name: Alan Kay
linkInfo: Kay became a “Fellow” at Apple; his Dynabook influenced Newton and iPad.

name: Alan Kay
linkInfo: Kay, Warnock, and Taylor worked at PARC.

name: Arturo Rosenblueth
linkInfo: Co-authors of “Behavior, Purpose, and Teleology”

name: Bill Atkinson
linkInfo: Atkinson’s HyperCard app influenced Berners-Lee.

name: Bob Taylor
linkInfo: Kay, Warnock, and Taylor worked at PARC.

name: Brian Eno
linkInfo: Beer’s Brain of the Firm influenced Emo, and the two later met.

name: Cedric Price
linkInfo: Pask collaborated with Price and Littlewood on the Fun Palace.

name: Christopher Alexander
linkInfo: Alexander adapted key ideas for Notes on the Synthesis of Form, from Ashby’s Design for a Brain.

name: Chuck Owen
linkInfo: Owen expanded Alexander’s software program to create his structured planning app.

name: Chuck Owen
linkInfo: Owen, Pask, Rittel, Archer, and Alexander attended the first DM Conference.

name: Claude Shannon
linkInfo: Shannon supervised Sutherland’s thesis project, which resulted in Sketchpad, one of the first examples of interactive computer graphics

name: Don Koberg
linkInfo: Bagnall and Koberg were students of Rittel at UC Berkeley.

name: Don Koberg
linkInfo: Bagnall and Koberg were students of Alexander at UC Berkeley.

name: Douglas Engelbart
linkInfo: Brand consulted with Engelbart’s team on staging the famous 1968 demo and operated a video camera during the demo.

name: Douglas Engelbart
linkInfo: When Taylor was at DARPA, he approved funding Engelbart’s research. However, Engelbart never collaborated with PARC, even though PARC re-implemented several of his ideas.

name: Fernando Flores
linkInfo: Flores and Winograd co-authored Understanding Computers and Cognition.

name: Fernando Flores
linkInfo: Maturana’s writing influenced Flores’ thinking.

name: Fernando Flores
linkInfo: Flores hired Beer to build CyberSyn

name: Gordon Pask
linkInfo: Pask wrote the introduction to Negroponte’s Soft Architecture Machines.

name: Gordon Pask
linkInfo: Glanville and Pangaro were students of Pask at Brunel.

name: Gordon Pask
linkInfo: Glanville and Pangaro were students of Pask at Brunel.

name: Gregory Bateson
linkInfo: Bateson's concept of “double bind” was similar to work Laing did. The two corresponded.

name: Gregory Bateson
linkInfo: Bateson influenced Brand, and he interviewed Bateson and his ex-wife Mead in 1976.

name: Gui Bonsiepe
linkInfo: Bonsiepe worked with Beer and Flores on CyberSyn.

name: Gui Bonsiepe
linkInfo: Bonsiepe worked with Beer and Flores on CyberSyn.

name: Heinz von Foerster
linkInfo: Von Foerster and Leary were friends.

name: Heinz von Foerster
linkInfo: Bateson introduced Brand to von Foerster, and von Foerster contributed reviews to Brand’s Whole Earth Catalog.

name: Heinz von Foerster
linkInfo: Von Foerster was a PhD thesis advisor for Rheinfrank.

name: Heinz von Foerster
linkInfo: Von Foerster and Chermayeff were friends.

name: Horst Rittel
linkInfo: Rittel and Alexander were colleagues in the College of Environmental Design at UC Berkeley.

name: Ivan Sutherland
linkInfo: Sutherland turned Utah into the premiere school for computer graphics in the mid 1960s.

name: Ivan Sutherland
linkInfo: Sutherland replaced Licklider at DARPA in 1964.

name: J.C.R. Licklider
linkInfo: Licklider and Taylor worked together at DARPA and became friends.

name: Jim Bagnall
linkInfo: Bagnall and Koberg were students of Rittel at UC Berkeley.

name: Jim Bagnall
linkInfo: Bagnall and Koberg were students of Alexander at UC Berkeley.

name: John Warnock (founded Adobe)
linkInfo: Kay, Warnock, and Taylor worked at PARC.

name: Julian Bigelow
linkInfo: Co-authors of “Behavior, Purpose, and Teleology”

name: Lou Danziger
linkInfo: Danziger was Plunkett’s teacher at CalArts.

name: Lou Danziger
linkInfo: Danziger was influenced by Wiener’s books.

name: Norbert Wiener
linkInfo: Wiener’s Cybernetics influenced Beer, Danziger, McLuhan, and Fuller.

name: Norbert Wiener
linkInfo: Worked together at MIT

name: Norbert Wiener
linkInfo: Wiener gave a lecture at HfG Ulm on July 14, 1955.

name: Norbert Wiener
linkInfo: Co-authors of “Behavior, Purpose, and Teleology”

name: Norbert Wiener
linkInfo: Co-authors of “Behavior, Purpose, and Teleology”

name: Norbert Wiener
linkInfo: Wiener’s Cybernetics influenced Beer, Danziger, McLuhan, and Fuller.

name: Norbert Wiener
linkInfo: Wiener’s Cybernetics influenced Beer, Danziger, McLuhan, and Fuller.

name: Norbert Wiener
linkInfo: Wiener’s Cybernetics influenced Beer, Danziger, McLuhan, and Fuller.

name: Paul Pangaro
linkInfo: Pangaro and Dubberly co-taught “Cybernetics + Design” at Stanford and co-authored a number of articles related to cybernetics.

name: R.D. Laing
linkInfo: Pickering claims Pask made Laing’s work the basis of his “Conversation Theory.”

name: Ranulph Glanville
linkInfo: Glanville was Haque’s teacher at the AA.

name: Serge Chermayeff
linkInfo: Chermayeff taught Alexander at Harvard.

name: Sergey Brin
linkInfo: Winograd was advisor to Brin and Page at Stanford.

name: Stafford Beer
linkInfo: Pickering claims Beer “conspired with Heinz von Foerster to offer him the position that took him to University of Illinois.”

name: Stafford Beer
linkInfo: Pickering claims “Beer and Pask actively collaborated in the work on biological and chemical computers.”

name: Stafford Beer
linkInfo: Pickering says Ashby’s homeostat and his idea of requisite variety were key influences on Beer. Beer also introduced Ashby and Pask in 1965.

name: Stafford Beer
linkInfo: Beer and McCulloch were friends.

name: Stewart Brand
linkInfo: Brand and Leary were friends.

name: Stewart Brand
linkInfo: Atkinson participated in Brand’s 1984 Hacker Conference.

name: Stewart Brand
linkInfo: Kelly edited later version of the Whole Earth Catalog.

name: Stewart Brand
linkInfo: Kesey was a friend of Brand’s, and the both lived in Palo Alto in the early 1960s.

name: Stewart Brand
linkInfo: Brand spent three months at the Media Lab and wrote a book about it.

name: Stewart Brand
linkInfo: McLuhan also influenced Brand.

name: Stewart Brand
linkInfo: Fuller’s notion of “comprehensive designer” and his systems approach greatly influenced Brand.

name: Stewart Brand
linkInfo: As an undergradutate, Brand saw a talk by Eames, which “got to me.”

name: Ted Nelson
linkInfo: Nelson and Pask both spent a year at University of Illinois at Chicago Circle and had office on the same floor. They discussed hypertext as Nelson was writing Dream Machines.

name: Ted Nelson
linkInfo: Von Foerster introduced Nelson to Leary, and they became friends.

name: Ted Nelson
linkInfo: Nelson participated in Brand’s 1984 Hacker Conference. Nelson and Brand now both live blocks apart on house boats in Sausilito.

name: Ted Nelson
linkInfo: Nelson’s ideas on hypertext influenced Atkinson’s HyperCard app.

name: Terry Winograd
linkInfo: Flores and Winograd co-authored Understanding Computers and Cognition.

name: Terry Winograd
linkInfo: Winograd participated in forming the D-School at Stanford, which helped launch and promoted “design thinking.”

name: Terry Winograd
linkInfo: Rheinfrank contributed “Design Languages” to Winograd’s Bringing Design to Software.

name: Terry Winograd
linkInfo: Von Foerster, Maturana, and Winograd helped found “Radical Constructivism.”

name: Terry Winograd
linkInfo: Von Foerster, Maturana, and Winograd helped found “Radical Constructivism.”

name: Timothy Leary
linkInfo: Leary and Kesey were friends.

name: Vannevar Bush
linkInfo: As a grad student Shannon worked on Bush’s differential analyzer

name: Vannevar Bush
linkInfo: Englebart was profoundly influenced by Bush’s “As We May Think”

name: Vannevar Bush
linkInfo: Nelson was influenced by Bush’s “As We May Think”

name: Warren McCulloch (Chair)
linkInfo: Beer and McCulloch were friends.

name: William Burroughs
linkInfo: Walter’s The Living Brain influenced Burroughs.
